title: Liber de arte distillandi - Complete Recipe Database
author: Hieronymus Brunschwig

R.notes: Contains 2 ANIMAL entries: Rinds gallen (ox gall), Regen würm (earthworm). Multiple rose varieties. Peony has stroke cure.

S.notes: St. John's wort, orchids (aphrodisiac), water lily (reduces lust), sage. Star jelly = best wound remedy.

V.notes: No V section in medieval German - merged into W/F

W.notes: Wormwood EXTENSIVE (legendary), Comfrey (bone healer), Hemlock (POISON - coldest), Mullein (noblest for swelling)

X.notes: Black hellebore (130-year-old man story), Sweet root

Z.notes: Onion, Daisy, Bryony (FINAL ENTRY). Book 2 ends here.

recipes.procedure_summary: Root, stem, and herb chopped together and distilled at the end of May
recipes.notes: Male and female varieties. Male for men, female for women.
NO PROCEDURE. Three varieties. One of the most versatile waters.

recipes.procedure_summary: Distilled from the white berries
recipes.notes: Grows on wild apple trees.
NO PROCEDURE. Like elderberry but not woody.

recipes.procedure_summary: Root and herb chopped together and distilled at end of May. Root alone is better.
recipes.notes: Fragrant root used for 'Alant wine'.

recipes.procedure_summary: Pound the root and distill per alembic
recipes.notes: Root only version, more potent than herb+root.

recipes.procedure_summary: OCR partially corrupted - distilled at end of...
recipes.notes: Produces burrs that stick to clothing.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb and stem chopped together when bearing flowers and distilled
recipes.notes: Mostly blue flowers. Use blue not white unless specified.

recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves stripped from stems, chopped and distilled at end of May
recipes.notes: Called 'liver thistle' - good for liver.

recipes.procedure_summary: Root and herb chopped together and distilled at end of May
recipes.notes: Has red spadix. Two roots hang together - one grows as other withers.

recipes.procedure_summary: Pound herb and root, distill at end of May
recipes.notes: DANGEROUS - STUPEFACTIVUM. WARNING: Fraudsters carve bryony roots into human shapes and sell as mandrake.

recipes.procedure_summary: OCR partial - procedure implied
key_uses: THE MOST NOBLE WATER FOR PLAGUE
recipes.notes: Most important plague remedy. Recipe: 2 lot water + 1 quintin theriac + half quintin powdered root + half lot vinegar.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb, flowers, root, stem with all substance chopped/pounded, distilled when flowering
recipes.notes: Blue flowers. Broad pointed hairy leaves with red spots.

recipes.procedure_summary: Young birds beginning to fly, plucked/chopped with all substance and distilled in clean vessels
recipes.timing: when young birds beginning to fly
recipes.notes: ANIMAL WATER. Common bird, white and black. Proven by old physician in Strasbourg.

recipes.procedure_summary: OCR SEVERELY CORRUPTED - cannot extract
recipes.notes: ANIMAL BLOOD WATER. OCR lines 4500-4536 are mostly unreadable symbols.

recipes.procedure_summary: Root and herb with all substance, chopped/pounded and distilled when bearing flowers
recipes.notes: Highly praised. Two kinds - wild (ox tongue) and tame.

recipes.procedure_summary: Break off flowering tips, chop and distill in balneum mariae
recipes.notes: More delicate than herb water. 'One of the highest waters for melancholy'.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb and root pounded together and distilled around St. John's Day (midsummer)
recipes.notes: SEDATIVE. Two kinds - white seed (USE THIS) and black seed (DO NOT USE).

recipes.procedure_summary: OCR partial
recipes.notes: Called 'Iris' (rainbow) due to many flower colors.

recipes.procedure_summary: Chop small and distill in March around St. Gertrude's day (March 17)
recipes.notes: Very versatile root water. 22+ uses from A to X.

recipes.procedure_summary: Small yellow inner parts distilled per balneum mariae
recipes.notes: Very specific - only the small inner parts. Restores speech wonderfully.

recipes.procedure_summary: Youngest leaves chopped/pounded and distilled in middle of May
recipes.notes: Tree with white bark.

recipes.procedure_summary: UNIQUE: In May, bore hole in birch tree, place glass beneath to collect sap, then distill per alembic
recipes.notes: UNIQUE METHOD - sap collected from living tree. One of few non-plant-material waters.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb, stem, and leaves chopped together and distilled at end of May
recipes.notes: Fleshy herb often eaten in salad. Cold nature - good for cooling.

recipes.procedure_summary: Small kind with sharp root - herb and roots chopped/pounded and distilled at end of May. Plants from dry/high places are better.
recipes.notes: Root tastes like ginger. Important note: plants from dry soil/mountains lack excess moisture so water lasts longer.

recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves stripped from newly-sprouted shoots, distilled in May
recipes.notes: Leaves similar to periwinkle.

recipes.procedure_summary: Distill at beginning of June
recipes.notes: More delicate than leaf water. Tested by Junker Conrad Klotz.

recipes.procedure_summary: Top shoots and leaves about a span long, chopped and distilled at end of May
recipes.notes: Grows in flowing water. Don't drink too much - harmful to stomach.

recipes.procedure_summary: Upper stems and leaves chopped together and distilled in middle of May
recipes.notes: Grows in streams with red stems where fish dwell.

recipes.procedure_summary: OCR partial
recipes.notes: Root water after bloodletting good against plague.

recipes.procedure_summary: Distill when flowers fully ripe but before turning black, in balneum mariae
recipes.timing: when flowers ripe but not spoiled
recipes.notes: Special recipe: soak in wine, press, distill, set in sun - makes beautiful complexion.

recipes.procedure_summary: While green, put in glass and distill in ventre equino (warm sand bath)
key_uses: bad bones - wash then powder residue and apply
recipes.notes: Many bean varieties. Use the residue (feces) as powder on wounds.

recipes.procedure_summary: Distill when Sun in Cancer and Moon in Aries
recipes.timing: ASTROLOGICAL: Sun in Cancer, Moon in Aries
key_uses: THE BEST WATER for gravel in loins/bladder
recipes.notes: Brunschwig calls this THE BEST water for gravel. Astrological timing specified.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb and stem distilled at end of May
recipes.notes: Green herb of common bean.

recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves and stem when not yet flowering
key_uses: paralysis and palsy - rub on limbs
recipes.notes: Greeks write 'b' but pronounce 'v'.

recipes.procedure_summary: Stem and leaves chopped and distilled in balneum mariae in June
recipes.notes: Called 'gariophillata' - tastes like cloves. Called 'epitima' (heart water) by philosophers.

recipes.procedure_summary: Distill in May when flowering
recipes.notes: BRUNSCHWIG ADMITS: 'I don't know this plant - I commend it to those who do.'

recipes.procedure_summary: Blood from UNCASTRATED male goat, collected during dog days (late July-August), and distilled
recipes.notes: ANIMAL BLOOD WATER. Two kinds: wild (ibex/steinbock) and tame. Must be uncastrated male.

recipes.procedure_summary: When leaf at strongest taste, around end of May, stripped and distilled
recipes.notes: Flowers like white roses. Red fruit with seeds like small stones.

recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves and stems of brown-flowered variety, distilled at end of May. Note: timing varies by climate and weather.
recipes.notes: ONE OF THE LONGEST ENTRIES - 28+ uses (A through BB). Important climate note: timing cannot always be exact, adjust for local conditions.

recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves stripped from branches and distilled at end of May
key_uses: body lice - shave, wash, rub, let dry
recipes.notes: Tree that feeds swine with its fruit (beechnuts).

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb and stem without root, chopped and distilled when flowering (June)
recipes.notes: NOT the same as ancient 'barba hircina'. Yellow flowers like dandelion. Sweet taste when chewed. Despite name, this is a PLANT not animal.

recipes.procedure_summary: When berries fully ripe but not soft, break off, wash, drain, distill
recipes.notes: Different from raspberry - blackberry has sharp thorns, raspberry has none.

recipes.procedure_summary: Whole herb gathered and chopped when flowering, distilled
recipes.notes: CRITICAL WARNING: 'KILLS THE CHILD' in pregnant women. Brunschwig wrote this warning to protect good women.

recipes.procedure_summary: Flowers distilled in March per alembic, herb in May. Balneum mariae is better.
recipes.notes: VERY LONG ENTRY - 37+ uses (A through KK). One of the most versatile waters. Contains cure for lost speech from cracked skull.

recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves stripped from stem and tops, from RED variety, distilled at end of May
recipes.notes: Called 'mother of herbs'. NOT St. John's wort (different plant). Has hidden power against sorcery. Brunschwig saw possessed person refuse to grasp this herb.

recipes.procedure_summary: Standard herb distillation
recipes.notes: THE LONGEST ENTRY IN THE ENTIRE BOOK - 50+ uses. Contains famous TOAD STORY: toad stung by spider ate plantain to heal, when herb removed toad swelled and died.

recipes.procedure_summary: Distill seed when ripe
Stem and flower distilled when small flowers appear (like grape flower)
Root and herb washed and chopped together, distilled at end of March
recipes.notes: Root tastes like cloves (hence Latin name). Often soaked in wine.

recipes.procedure_summary: Root (not herb) chopped and distilled at end of March
recipes.notes: Three kinds: wild and tame. Wild called 'daucus'. Related to 'bird's nest' plant.

recipes.procedure_summary: Root and stem when bearing pods and flowers, washed and chopped, distilled
recipes.notes: Cold and moist nature. Many varieties including 'ybiſch' (marshmallow). One of the most versatile.

recipes.procedure_summary: Flowers from small mallow distilled when ripe
Herb, stem with flowers chopped at end of May and distilled
recipes.notes: Similar to golden bugle but different flower color. Both have similar power.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb and root with all substance distilled at beginning of June
key_uses: purge head via nose - draws out eye/nose/ear drips
expels excess heat and gross moisture
heals old open wounds with wine
recipes.notes: Called 'ſchißmilt' (shit-milt) because it moves bowels. Not the same as 'gut heinrich' despite some confusion.
See entry 42 - same plant, different spelling variant.

recipes.procedure_summary: OCR CORRUPTED - lines unreadable
recipes.notes: OCR severely corrupted at this section.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb and flowers chopped together and distilled in June
recipes.notes: LONGEST ENTRY IN SECTION C - 35+ uses (A through EE). Three kinds: true chamomile, stinking chamomile (Cotula fetida), non-stinking (Cotula non fetida). Only true chamomile should be used.

recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves chopped and distilled at end of May
recipes.notes: THREE FAMOUS CASES: (1) Girl in Pavia cured from apple poisoning, (2) Snake expelled from man's throat, (3) Woman's breast cancer cured by Bishop of Augsburg. Important plague remedy.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb, stem, and leaves chopped and distilled at end of May
recipes.notes: Called 'sticky plant' because leaves stick to tongue. Grows near dead nettles and flax. Praised as SUPREME jaundice remedy.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb and stem with flowers chopped and distilled in June
recipes.notes: Grows in cultivated fields near onions, cabbage, beets. Another jaundice remedy in Section C.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb without root chopped, pounded, and distilled mid-June
recipes.notes: UNIQUE frostbite prevention: distill around St. John Baptist day (June 24), set in sun 14 days, rub on body. Prevents freezing until washed off.

recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves broken from stalks and distilled in June
recipes.notes: Common vegetable. Focus on kidney/urinary tract issues. Section C ends here.

recipes.procedure_summary: Stem, leaves, and flowers chopped and distilled at end of June
recipes.notes: Name etymology: should be 'hundred gold' not 'thousand gold' (centum=100, aurum=gold). Also called 'fever herb'. Two varieties: greater and lesser centaury.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb and stem with all substance chopped and distilled at end of May
recipes.notes: Important plague remedy. Blood purifying. Makes disfigured face 'pale and natural-colored'. Sweat therapy with bath for scabies.

recipes.procedure_summary: Root, herb, and stem with all substance chopped and distilled at end of May
recipes.notes: Called 'cat herb' because cats love the root. IMPORTANT DISTINCTION: Cats eat ROOT of valerian but LEAVES of catnip (different plant). Specific timing 'between the two Mary days'. Multiple plague uses.

recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves, stem, and root chopped and distilled at end of May
recipes.notes: Similar to endive but produces milk (endive doesn't). Related to lettuce family. Cooling properties for fever.

recipes.procedure_summary: Multiple methods: (1) Mix with sand, distill in rose-hat; (2) Seal in glass, bury in ant hill 8 days; (3) Add salt, place in damp cellar until liquefied
recipes.notes: UNIQUE preparation methods including ant hill fermentation. PROVEN by Count Jacob von Lichtenberg. Early OCR corrupted.

recipes.procedure_summary: Root with herb chopped and distilled at end of May; or root alone at end of dog days (better)
recipes.timing: end of May (herb+root) or end of dog days (root only, better)
recipes.notes: OCR SEVERELY CORRUPTED. Very bitter root. Root-only distillation preferred.

recipes.procedure_summary: Leafy tops pounded with vinegar, steeped 5-6 days, then distilled mid-May
recipes.notes: Two ash varieties: common and stone ash. UNIQUE vinegar maceration pre-treatment. Focus on skin conditions.

recipes.procedure_summary: Distilled at end of May; root distilled at end of dog days
recipes.timing: end of May (herb) or end of dog days (root)
recipes.notes: VERY LONG ENTRY - 33 uses (A through GG). Multiple fennel varieties described. Important for eye conditions. Increases breast milk for wet nurses.

recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves with thorns removed, distilled at end of May
recipes.notes: Called 'Our Lady's thistle' - legend says white spots are drops of Virgin Mary's milk. Good for children.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb and root chopped and distilled at end of May
recipes.notes: Only 2 uses but both for serious conditions. Important plague remedy.

recipes.procedure_summary: Cultivated herb and stem with flowers distilled when flowering
recipes.notes: Also called 'trinity flower' (Driualtigkeit) for three-colored blooms (yellow, blue, white). Named after childhood illness 'freissam'.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb, stem, root with all substance chopped and distilled mid-May
recipes.notes: PROVEN by goldsmith Adam Teufel in Strasbourg for trembling hands. Strong laxative. Excellent early treatment for swellings.
HEADER ONLY - 'Von frösch waſſer' appears but NO RECIPE TEXT FOLLOWS. Entry is MISSING or was never completed. Confirms earlier triangulation finding that frog procedure is unverifiable.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb, flowers, and stem with all substance distilled mid-May
recipes.notes: Contains POEM distinguishing three bugle types. Stroke recovery - restores speech. Black tongue fever uses bresil seeds.

recipes.procedure_summary: Whole herb distilled in June
recipes.notes: Short entry. Leaves similar to chard but smaller.

recipes.procedure_summary: With all substance chopped and distilled mid-May
recipes.notes: Called 'blue flower herb'. Excellent for liver when distilled with flowers.

recipes.procedure_summary: Root and herb chopped and distilled between the two Mary days
recipes.notes: Named 'goose herb' because geese love to eat it.

recipes.procedure_summary: Flowers distilled per alembicum when fully ripe
recipes.notes: Flower-only water. PRAISED AS ABSOLUTE BEST FOR DIZZINESS.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb and stem chopped and distilled at beginning of June
recipes.notes: Important PLAGUE remedy. Unique: drink in bath for internal phlegm.

recipes.procedure_summary: Tops/heads distilled when fully ripe, near end of May
recipes.notes: 17 uses - long entry! Notable for fertility, heart conditions, stroke recovery, restoring senses.

recipes.procedure_summary: OCR CORRUPTED
recipes.notes: OCR CORRUPTED. Entry incomplete. Two forms mentioned.

recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves distilled mid-May
recipes.notes: Called 'liver herb' for its liver benefits.

recipes.procedure_summary: Flowers distilled when fully ripe but not yet falling
recipes.notes: Called 'sword-root' for sword-shaped leaves. Only 1 use. Cross-ref to blue iris in Section B.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb and stem distilled at end of May
recipes.notes: Includes DETAILED treatment for red spots: honey, compress, bloodletting, dietary restrictions. Distinguished from watercress.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb and stem chopped and distilled at end of May
recipes.notes: Called 'urine herb' because it promotes urination. Also 'flax herb' for resemblance. THE BEST for red eyes.

recipes.procedure_summary: Peel outer gray bark, then inner green bark, distill per alembicum in balneum mariae at beginning of May
recipes.notes: Inner green bark used, not outer gray bark.

recipes.procedure_summary: Leafy tips and leaves chopped and distilled mid-May
recipes.notes: Three kinds: sambucus, ebulus (dwarf elder), and sambucus rubeus.

recipes.procedure_summary: Strip flowers from stalks when fully ripe and distill
recipes.notes: 15 uses - long entry. Heats and dries. Opens liver/spleen/kidney blockages.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb, leaves, stem, flower, and root with all substance chopped and distilled at end of June
recipes.notes: Named for leaf shape resembling dog's tongue. Red flowers.

recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves distilled in May
recipes.notes: 16 uses. PRINCIPAL remedy for spleen with wild tamarisk. Can make spleen hard as stone then heals it over 40 days.

recipes.procedure_summary: Mix white honey with clean washed sand, distill gently (first clear water, then yellow water); OR seal honey in glass, bury in horse dung 14 days (renew weekly), then distill per alembicum
key_uses: PLAGUE (complex recipe with gold, myrrh, saffron)
recipes.notes: Best honey is white, from bees far from sea/unclean places. Mix with sand to prevent boiling over. TWO methods given. PLAGUE recipe includes aloe, myrrh, saffron, and gold leaf.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb only chopped and distilled at end of May
recipes.notes: Called 'thunder bar' - planted on houses against lightning. VERY COLD - colder than pepper. NOT for internal use without mixing.

recipes.names_latin: herba paralisis, herba artetica, primula veris
recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves and flowers with all substance chopped and distilled at beginning of spring
recipes.notes: Called 'heaven's key' or 'Peter's key'. Primula veris is actually meadow saffron - distinction noted.

recipes.procedure_summary: Root and herb with all substance chopped and distilled between the two Mary days
recipes.notes: ⚠️ SEVERE WARNING: Pregnant women MUST NOT drink this - it drives out child (dead or alive). If pregnant woman drinks, not only child dies but she dies instantly too - body and soul both dead.

recipes.procedure_summary: Inner yellow lining stripped from chicken stomach, distilled per alembicum in balneum mariae
recipes.notes: ANIMAL WATER (fire degree 4). Inner membrane only. Unique use for eye alignment.

recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves, herb, and flowers stripped from stem before sunrise, chopped and distilled when flowers are fully ripe
key_uses: weak/sick/dim eyes (THE BEST - 1-3 drops + rub + look at green places)
recipes.notes: Harvest before sunrise. THE BEST for weak eyes. Look at green places after use.

recipes.procedure_summary: Root and herb with all substance chopped and distilled mid-May
recipes.notes: Two types: round (hollow or not) and long. Called 'hinisch krut' for horse treatment. Distinct from 'ye lenger ye lieber' (bittersweet).

recipes.procedure_summary: ⭐CRITICAL: Take good BLACK hens 2-3 years old, STRANGLE (don't bleed), pluck WITHOUT SCALDING, remove ALL FAT, chop into small pieces, first distill on helm, then transfer to glass and redistill per balneum mariae
recipes.method: double distillation: first on helm, then per balneum mariae
key_uses: severely wasted/weak/powerless patients - gives extraordinary strength (doctors marvel)
recipes.notes: ⭐⭐⭐ VALIDATED TRIANGULATION ENTRY ⭐⭐⭐ Voynich token: eoschso (f90r1:6). UNIQUE among animals: AUX+e_ESCAPE+FLOW+k_ENERGY pattern. BLACK hens required. DOUBLE DISTILLATION. Only 1 use but procedure fully documented.

recipes.procedure_summary: When medium stag sheds antlers and regrows them half-ell length while still soft (like cartilage), chop and distill
recipes.timing: when antlers soft and newly regrown (half ell)
key_uses: stops excessive menstruation - PROVEN by Junker Matheus von Burn
recipes.notes: ANIMAL WATER (fire degree 4). Uses SOFT newly-regrown antlers, not hard mature ones. Noble testimonial.

recipes.procedure_summary: Front tips when first growing 2 spans long, chopped and distilled at end of April
key_uses: purifies blood, expels melancholy (causes scabs, itching, leprosy appearance)
recipes.notes: Young 2-span tips only. Not the hop cones used for beer. Purifies unclean blood from spleen problems.

recipes.procedure_summary: Male plant (blue flowers) with all substance, chopped and distilled around St. John the Baptist's eve
recipes.notes: Two types: male (blue flowers) and female (yellow flowers). Male preferred. Also called 'iron herb' because its sap hardens iron like steel.

recipes.procedure_summary: Berries distilled in second autumn month when fully ripe
recipes.notes: Also called 'Schluttẽ' or 'Boberellen'. Red berries in red bladder-like husk. THE BEST water for kidney stones. Can also distill herb in June but less potent.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb distilled (timing not specified in text)
recipes.notes: Good for maintaining health in wise understanding people.

recipes.procedure_summary: Root distilled
recipes.notes: Cold and moist. Softens hard things.

recipes.procedure_summary: Naturally growing herb distilled at end of May
recipes.notes: Ground-creeping plant with leaves like beech but pointed. Used for making garlands for dancing.

recipes.procedure_summary: Stripped from stem, chopped and distilled mid-May
recipes.notes: Very cold. Also called 'shepherd's rod' or 'broom straw'. Leaves hold water.

recipes.procedure_summary: Water that collects naturally in teasel leaves, gathered around May, placed in glass in sun 40 days, then filtered (per filtrum)
recipes.timing: around May, then 40 days in sun
recipes.notes: SPECIAL PREPARATION: Not distilled but naturally collected + sun-aged + filtered. Maidens keep it for face beautification.

recipes.procedure_summary: Procedure not detailed in text
recipes.notes: Garden herb with umbrella-like flower clusters. Interesting note: safe for pregnant/nursing women.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb, stem and root with all substance, chopped and distilled mid-May
recipes.notes: Two elbow heights tall.

recipes.procedure_summary: Root pounded and distilled during dog days
recipes.notes: Wild garlic (scordon) grows wild on cliffs. Tame garlic grown in gardens.

recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves and flowers distilled mid-May
recipes.notes: Red clover flowers called 'flesh blossoms' in Alsace because they're flesh-colored.

recipes.procedure_summary: Fruit chopped and distilled when fully ripe but before softening (more astringent = better)
recipes.notes: Mix with rough red wine (styptic). More astringent = better quality.

recipes.procedure_summary: Blossoms distilled when fully ripe
recipes.notes: Separate recipe from quince fruit.

recipes.procedure_summary: Fruit chopped when fully ripe, with seeds and all, distilled
recipes.notes: Not to be confused with coloquintida (bitter apple) which strongly purges. Common gourd discussed here.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb distilled mid-May
recipes.notes: Called 'cat's tail' but should be called 'horse tail' (cauda = tail, equus = horse). Cold in 1st degree, dry in 2nd with much stypticity. Master Bernhard the Carthusian surgeon verified.

recipes.procedure_summary: Dung from cows grazing on meadows with many flowers, collected mid-May, dried slightly in sun, distilled. If smells bad, add almond/peach kernels or redistill per alembicum
key_uses: ⭐ PLAGUE (from castrated ox - PROVEN AND VERIFIED)
recipes.notes: ⚠️ PLAGUE CURE: Water from castrated ox dung is proven remedy for pestilence.

recipes.procedure_summary: Blood from BLACK calf (blacker = better), distilled mid-May if available
recipes.notes: ANIMAL BLOOD WATER (fire degree 4). BLACK calf specifically required - blacker = better.

recipes.procedure_summary: Blood and lung from BLACK calf, chopped together and distilled per alembicum secundum artem
key_uses: wasting limbs (rub + drink + mix with drinks for whole-body wasting) - PROVEN
recipes.notes: ANIMAL BLOOD+ORGAN WATER (fire degree 4). Combined distillation. For severe whole-body wasting, drink + rub.

recipes.procedure_summary: Liver from BLACK calf if available, distilled
recipes.notes: ANIMAL ORGAN WATER (fire degree 4). BLACK calf preferred.

recipes.procedure_summary: Petals distilled at start of June (Brachmonat)
recipes.notes: Called 'clapper roses' because they pop when clapped on fist. Also called 'corn roses' because they grow red in grain fields.

recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves distilled at start of June
key_uses: ⚠️ KILLS UNBORN + CAUSES PREMATURE BIRTH (LIFE THREATENING)
aids birth at proper time (cloth on scham)
recipes.notes: ⚠️ SEVERE WARNING: Pregnant women MUST NOT drink - kills child + causes premature birth + life-threatening. Brunschwig hopes good people will keep this secret. At proper birth time, apply cloth externally only.

recipes.procedure_summary: Take BLACK capon 3-5 years old, strangle, pluck WITHOUT scalding, remove all fat and guts, wash entrails clean, chop head/neck/wings/stomach/feet/whole body into small pieces, distill per alembicum or on helm, then REDISTILL per alembicum into glass
recipes.method: double distillation: first on helm/alembic, then redistill
key_uses: wasted/weakened body from overexertion (restores body + refreshes spirit)
brings appetite + strengthens nature/body + expels sickness from heart
recipes.notes: ⭐ ANIMAL WATER (fire degree 4) - SIMILAR TO CHICKEN! BLACK capon, 3-5 years. Same procedure: strangle, dry pluck, de-fat, chop, DOUBLE DISTILL. For gold addition, see Brunschwig's larger book.

recipes.procedure_summary: Curly type first, then smooth type, herb only distilled mid-May
recipes.notes: Three types: domestic (curly/smooth), wild (goose thistle/endive), and donkey lettuce (red root). Curly type preferred.

recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves and stems chopped together and distilled mid-May
recipes.notes: Called 'love herb' because its water makes one's skin beautiful. Leaves like parsley but broader. Hollow stem.

recipes.procedure_summary: Blossoms from broad-leafed linden distilled in June when fully ripe
recipes.notes: Two types: large-leaf and small-leaf (stone linden). Many in Germany, rare in Italy. THE NOBLEST water for eyes - makes clear sight.

recipes.procedure_summary: Root only distilled in June
recipes.notes: Various types of leek (discussed under E for garlic leek, K for garlic). White root like young onion.

recipes.procedure_summary: First blossoms distilled at start of June
key_uses: shin sores (PROVEN by Master Gotthard of Jülich)
recipes.notes: Also called 'Our Lady's lily' or 'bacon lily'. Blooms twice yearly. Climbing vine like grapes. Master Gotthard (Duke of Jülich's surgeon) testified. Can add herb for external use (stronger).

recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves carefully picked and distilled end of May/start of June
key_uses: liver strengthening + removes obstruction + removes unnatural heat
recipes.notes: Three herbs called 'liver herb' in German (only this one in Latin). Others: waldmeister (mater silva/herba stellaris) and golden clover. Grows in old wells and moist stony cliffs. Small overlapping leaves like lungwort.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb and flowers chopped together and distilled in June
key_uses: epilepsy + paralysis + sleeping limbs (drink + rub 3-4 weeks)
prevents bread mold (add small amount to dough water)
recipes.notes: Two types: common lavender and spike lavender (from Provence, also now in Germany). Spike lavender makes oleum de spica (discussed in larger book). Common lavender discussed here.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb with all substance distilled (timing not specified)
recipes.notes: Also called 'mother herb' or 'heart herb'. EXTENSIVE uses (A-OO!). Good for mother (uterus) pain. Keeps meat fresh when sprinkled.

recipes.procedure_summary: Only the little flowers distilled mid-May
recipes.notes: Called 'May flowers' because worn in May. Queen of England made water from flowers for remarkable eye treatments. The NOBLEST water for eyes.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb distilled
recipes.notes: Grows on old walls with small berry-like leaves. Also called 'cat grapes' or 'wall grapes'.

recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves stripped from stem/bush distilled at end of May
recipes.notes: Very noble plant.

recipes.names_latin: milium solis, grana solis, cauda porcina
recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves stripped from stem and distilled at end of May
recipes.notes: Called 'stone-breaking herb'. Seeds are white and hard like small round stones, size of coriander. Also called 'pig's tail'.

recipes.procedure_summary: Root chopped, pounded and distilled between the two Mary days
key_uses: internal bleeding from injury (with hemp seed + chervil water + sugar)
recipes.notes: Root curved like small snake with tail. Different from 'serpentaria' (great snakewort) which has snake-spotted stem. PLAGUE REMEDY PROVEN.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb distilled at end of May/June
recipes.notes: Called 'cat herb' because cats love to eat it. Different from valerian ('denmarck') which cats love for its ROOT. Goldsmith Jerg Ziechel of Würzburg (1466) used denmarck root powder daily to maintain sharp eyesight for intricate engraving work.

recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves stripped from stems and distilled when bearing green berries
recipes.notes: Three types: deadly (dolwurtz), red (ground cherry/Jew's cherry), and common (this one). Has hidden power that philosophers write about - drives back and resolves through sweat pores.

recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves and flowers stripped from stems and distilled around St. Margaret's day (July 20)
recipes.notes: Several types: dead nettle, small nettle, common nettle. Red nettle water especially good for wounds.

recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves, stems and flowers with all substance distilled
recipes.notes: Called 'eye comfort' or 'eye clear' for its WONDROUS power to clear, strengthen, and invigorate sight. Queen of England's physician did remarkable things with this for eyes.

recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves, herb and root with stems chopped together and distilled at end of May
recipes.notes: Also called 'hinsch krut' (horse herb) because horses are driven away by it hung around neck. Different from 'bittersweet' (ye lenger ye lieber).

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb distilled
recipes.notes: Also called 'wild sage'. Good for cold conditions.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb distilled
recipes.notes: Leaf shape like ox tongue.

recipes.procedure_summary: Mushrooms from clean/pure places distilled when fully ripe
recipes.notes: COLD nature up to 3rd degree - NOT GOOD TO DRINK internally. Many types: morels (spring), red with white spots (fly agaric - kills flies). Use externally only.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb distilled
recipes.notes: Wild and tame varieties. Wild type from Macedonia where only women rule. Very important culinary and medicinal herb.

recipes.procedure_summary: ⭐ Herb, stem, root with all substance chopped and distilled at end of June (Brachmonat)
key_uses: daily fever (with wormwood - PROVEN by great doctor)
recipes.notes: ⭐⭐⭐ VALIDATED TRIANGULATION ENTRY ⭐⭐⭐ Voynich token: keolo (tentative). Called 'hüner kull' (chicken herb) because stuffed into chickens. Also called 'wild pennyroyal'. One span high. Warm and dry. Great doctor PROVEN daily fever cure with wormwood. Medicine for poor people.

recipes.procedure_summary: Sap collected from vine, distilled
recipes.notes: Sap drops collected when placed near fire. Multiple application methods.

recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves from French/noble white grapes growing in sunny heights, distilled end of May
key_uses: pregnant women (prevents unnatural cravings harming child)
recipes.notes: Multiple grapevine types described: wild (bryonia), black (vitis silvestris), white (smerwurtz/lard root). Text distinguishes domestic vine clearly.

recipes.procedure_summary: ⭐ Gall from BLACK ox or cattle (preferred), distilled per alembicum in July/dog days
key_uses: unnamed worm on finger (cloth soaked, bound 2-3 times)
recipes.notes: ⭐ ANIMAL PRODUCT (fire degree 4) - Black ox/cattle gall preferred. Distilled in hot summer months.

recipes.procedure_summary: Root chopped small and distilled at start of first autumn month
recipes.notes: Two types: horseradish (major) and common radish (minor). VERY extensive uses A through GG. Warm and dry nature.

recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves distilled at start of June (Brachmonat)
key_uses: sores on hands/feet (bath with salt 2-3 days)
recipes.notes: Separate entry for radish leaves vs radish root.

recipes.procedure_summary: ⭐ Leaves stripped with flowers from stem when flowering, distilled - can be done TWICE yearly (May best, or early autumn)
recipes.timing: May (best) or early autumn - TWICE yearly possible
key_uses: strengthens brain and all internal organs
MAINTAINS YOUTH (stetig use, body ages not except in very long time)
recipes.notes: ⭐⭐ REMARKABLE ENTRY ⭐⭐ 'Wondrous properties' - one of the most praised herbs. 'BATH OF LIFE' (bad des lebens) delays aging. Can bury rosemary flowers in sand for a month to make water with BALSAM-LIKE power. Uses A through KK. Flower called 'anthos' in Latin.

recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves stripped from herb with flowers when flowering, chopped and distilled in dog days (July-August)
recipes.notes: Dried flower called 'wurm sat' (worm seed) by Germans - given fasting to children kills worms without expelling them.

recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves stripped from stalks, chopped and distilled in June (Brachmonat)
recipes.notes: Also called curly kale (kruser köl).

recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves broken from stalks, chopped and distilled end of May
recipes.notes: Common herb widely known.

recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves stripped from stems and distilled mid-May
key_uses: bad eyes (removes films/spots, makes sight sharp enough to see stars by day)
all venomous animal bites (can substitute for theriac)
recipes.notes: ⭐ VERY EXTENSIVE entry (A through RR). Two types: wild and tame. Warning: DANGEROUS for pregnant women - causes premature birth. Distinguishes from 'mur rut' (maidenhair fern) and 'Abrut' (fumitory). Can substitute for theriac against poison.

recipes.procedure_summary: ⭐ Collection method: Soak onions overnight in water, pour on rich/manured earth, worms emerge. Put in moss to clean. BEST worms from CHURCHYARDS or from gravediggers. Then distill.
key_uses: stops joint fluid in wounds (warm, with cotton)
all eye ailments (with camphor, hour before night)
recipes.notes: ⭐⭐ ANIMAL WATER (fire degree 4) ⭐⭐ Called 'ulwürm' or 'regenwürm' (emerge when it rains). Collection involves onion-soaked water on manured earth. BEST from churchyards/gravediggers - implies corpse-fed worms are most potent. Remarkable wound-healing properties.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb, stems and flowers chopped together and distilled at start of June (Brachmonat)
key_uses: red eyes/eye swelling (cloth, removes redness, makes clear)
unnatural heat with weakness/faintness (mixed with rose, bugloss, and ribwort waters)
recipes.notes: Named for spur-shaped flowers. Plant is 1.5 ells high. Multiple compound recipes given.

recipes.procedure_summary: Whole herb with all substance distilled end of May
key_uses: eye nail/growth (drop in eye, hour before night, 3-4 weeks)
recipes.notes: Grows in corn/grain fields with small purple flowers. NOT black coriander (nigella) despite some Latin claims. Name from German 'rat' (darnel).

recipes.names_latin: rosa, rosa rubea (red), rosa alba (white), rosa silvestris (wild)
recipes.procedure_summary: When fully ripe and just starting to open, petals picked and distilled. (General knowledge - no specific detailed procedure)
recipes.notes: Multiple rose types: Venetian (peonia), red tame, white tame filled, heath/wild (rosa silvestris), hips/buttenrosen (rosa bedagar). RED tame roses for strengthening. WHITE filled for best taste. HEATH roses for cooling. NO DETAILED PROCEDURE - rose water production widely known. Will describe in 'larger book'.

recipes.procedure_summary: Petals from cultivated red roses distilled
key_uses: strengthens/cools brain, heart, stomach, principal organs
recipes.notes: CULTIVATED red roses - better than wild roses for all strengthening. Cold and dry nature. Extensive uses A through S.

recipes.procedure_summary: Petals from cultivated white filled roses distilled in balneum mariae
key_uses: weakness/faintness (apply to forehead, temples, eyes, neck, wrists)
recipes.notes: Cultivated white FILLED roses. Best tasting of all rose waters. Must be distilled in balneum mariae (water bath).

recipes.procedure_summary: Wild rose hips/flowers distilled
recipes.notes: Wild roses (eglantine). Called 'rosa vini' (wine rose) for wine-like sharpness in taste. COLDEST of all rose types. Also called 'wich hag' roses - avoid the sharp thorns.

recipes.procedure_summary: Rose petals picked from buds just as they open, yellow stamens (antera) removed, then distilled
recipes.timing: just as roses begin to open
key_uses: stops bowel movements (dysentery from heat, white flux - lienteria)
recipes.notes: Best from cultivated red roses, then wild/heath, then white, least from hip roses. Remove yellow stamens (antera/rosen samen). Text clarifies true rose seed is very small and black, found under dried stamens.

recipes.procedure_summary: Roses when fully ripe, mixed with ROOT (2x weight of flower), pounded and distilled when flower fully ripe
key_uses: stroke/paralysis that prevents speech (REMARKABLE - person WILL speak again without doubt)
recipes.notes: Also called Venetian roses. ROOT is critical component (2x the weight of flowers). Remarkable claim for stroke recovery restoring speech.

recipes.procedure_summary: Entry incomplete in OCR - multiple turnip varieties described but no clear procedure
recipes.notes: Multiple varieties: wild and tame, long turnips (steckrüblin), yellow, red. Entry appears truncated in OCR before uses section. Includes napus (rape/canola).

recipes.names_latin: ypericon, scopia regia, herba sancti Johannis, perforatorium
recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves and flowers stripped from stems, distilled end of June (Brachmonat)
key_uses: intestinal flux (with red wine, or cloth on belly)
recipes.notes: Called 'herba de fuga demonis' (herb for driving out demons) - if held hidden in hand and offered to possessed person, they won't take hand. Perforated leaves (tiny holes like finest needle). Rue has similar anti-demon property.

recipes.procedure_summary: Jelly-like growth found on rotting wood (especially oak) or old fallow fields, distilled end of May or June
key_uses: old wounds/bone injuries/open sores (THE BEST and most proven remedy one can find)
recipes.notes: Mysterious gelatinous substance appearing on rotting wood like a galrey (jelly). Best from oak wood. Green color, found on old fields with weckholter (juniper). Praised as THE BEST wound remedy.

recipes.procedure_summary: Root distilled end of May
recipes.notes: Male orchid with two tubers like nutmegs (Knabenkraut). Also called 'rag wurtz'. Flower appears during Passion Week (crütz blümen). APHRODISIAC properties.

recipes.procedure_summary: Root distilled end of May (same as male)
key_uses: heals old and new wounds internal and external
recipes.notes: Female orchid (Hendel wurtz) with hand-shaped tubers (palma cristi). Also has APHRODISIAC properties like male.

recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves and flowers stripped from stems, distilled end of June
key_uses: confused/disturbed senses (cloth wrapped around head when they would rage) - RECOMMENDED FOR PRINCES AND LORDS and unwise people who think too much
recipes.notes: Also called 'long clover' or 'yellow clover'. Grows on stony paths with yellow flowers. Mental calming properties - explicitly recommended for nobility and overthinkers.

recipes.procedure_summary: Chopped and distilled at end of May
key_uses: hernia in men (9 mornings, 3 lot - heals without doubt)
recipes.notes: A type of fern (Osmunda), not known to everyone. Remarkable claim for hernia cure.

recipes.procedure_summary: White flowers distilled when fully ripe, before they turn black or rot (herb doesn't digest)
key_uses: white morphea (actually better for RED morphea from heat)
CONSUMES SPERM/weakens reproductive organs/REMOVES EXCESSIVE LUST
recipes.notes: White and yellow varieties (distinguished by flower color). Root called 'koller wurtzel'. Very COLD nature - specifically noted to REDUCE sexual desire and consume sperm. NOT the same as 'horstrang' (peucedanum).

recipes.names_latin: saxifraga major, saxifraga minor, saxifraga alba, saxifraga rubea
recipes.procedure_summary: Small green herb distilled start of June; larger variety with underground red seed mid-May
recipes.notes: Name means 'stone-breaker' for its power to break kidney/bladder stones. Multiple varieties: major (white flowers, red underground seed), minor (small spreading herb), alba (white seed), rubea (red berries = ground cherry/judenkersen). Also called 'grüen krut' (green herb).

recipes.procedure_summary: Small-leafed variety (like feathers) chopped with all substance, distilled end of May
key_uses: cleanses breast/preserves lungs/drives out side abscess
recipes.notes: Name from 'scabies' (scabs/scaly skin) which it treats. Three varieties: large (cut leaves like plantain), small (feathery leaves like fennel), broad-leafed (pastenmon). Warm and dry in 2nd degree.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb distilled when flowering
key_uses: wound bleeding (with tree moss - usnea - or cotton)
recipes.notes: Cross-references clary sage in letter O. Large-leafed sage. VERY extensive entry with uses A through BB+. One of the most important medicinal herbs.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb distilled
recipes.notes: Also called 'house leek' - grows on roofs. Very cold nature.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb with all substance distilled
key_uses: eye diseases (named after swallows who use it)
recipes.notes: Named for swallows (chelidon) who supposedly use it to restore sight to blind chicks. Yellow sap.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb distilled
recipes.notes: Diuretic properties. Good for urinary tract.

recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves and fruit distilled together when fruit ripe and red
key_uses: swelling (drives out through urine, use with bath)
recipes.notes: Also called 'hanhodal' (rooster testicles) for shape of red fruit. Wood used to make spindles. A shrub, not a large tree.

recipes.procedure_summary: Stems and leaves distilled at start of full growth
recipes.notes: Named 'sprink körner' (jumping seeds) - when ripe, seeds spring away. Milky stem like largest wolfsmilk. Stems 2 ells high. Purgative properties.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb and stems chopped when flowering, distilled end of June
recipes.notes: Also called 'wol gemůt' (well-minded) or 'rot kost' (red herb).

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb distilled
recipes.notes: Also called 'rot wurtz' (red root) or 'blut wurtz' (blood root) - red colored root that stops bleeding.

recipes.procedure_summary: Bark scraped from wood and leaves stripped, chopped together and distilled mid-May
recipes.notes: Shrub 3-4 ells high, like savin juniper. In heathen lands grows as large tree with fruit. By the Rhine, never seen with fruit. PRINCIPAL REMEDY for all spleen diseases.

recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves and tops (dolden/gypffel) stripped from stems, distilled end of May
key_uses: WONDROUS properties - sign given to army commanders for victory (legendary)
genital growths in men and women
protects paper from mice/worms (mixed with ink)
recipes.notes: ⭐⭐ VERY EXTENSIVE entry (A through LL+) ⭐⭐ LEGENDARY properties - sap/juice given to army commanders as sign of victory. Multiple varieties: romanum, dulce, cretensi, marinum (sea wormwood), ponticum. Also 'wurm sat' (worm seed) from Genoa. Has PARADOXICAL nature - stops bowels if constipated, promotes if excessive.

recipes.procedure_summary: Root only - washed, scraped, and distilled mid-May
key_uses: fresh wounds (cloth - PROVEN by Hans, priest of Würzburg, a famous wound doctor)
NOT GOOD alone for healthy people (too strong in healing)
recipes.notes: Also called 'Beinwel' (bone-well) or 'schwartz wurtz' (black root) - outer root is black. Root only for distillation. WARNING: Not good for healthy people alone - too strong. PRINCIPAL remedy for broken bones.

recipes.procedure_summary: Leaves from WHITE willows (felber) stripped from first-year shoots, distilled mid-May
key_uses: gravel expulsion (visible sand in chamber pot)
recipes.notes: Three types: sproß wide, hor widen, wilgen. White willow (felber) leaves are best. Male (red) and female (white) varieties have different properties. Young first-year shoots are strongest.

recipes.procedure_summary: Flowers distilled as with apple and peach blossoms
key_uses: facial skin problems (cloth 2-3x daily for 2-3 days)
recipes.notes: Cross-references apple blossom and peach blossom entries.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb and stem distilled mid-May. Hollow stem 3.5 ells high.
key_uses: St. Anthony's fire/hellish fire (THE COLDEST of all waters)
prevents breast enlargement in young women
hot dropsy (2x daily winter, 3x daily summer)
swallowed fly expulsion (1 lot morning fasting)
recipes.notes: ⚠️ POISON ⚠️ Called 'wütterich' (rager) - eating it causes madness. THE COLDEST water - one of the cold poison types. WARNING: DO NOT TAKE INTERNALLY. Author made pens from its hollow stem. External use only for cooling.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb with white bell flowers (grows on fences), distilled mid-May
recipes.notes: Multiple varieties: large bells on fences (fumus arbor/tree rope), small on ground (volubilis minor), scammony type with milky root like gourd. All 'wind' plants climb/bind on other plants.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb and root chopped together, distilled mid-May
key_uses: black plague blisters (cloth 3x day/night every 8 hours)
recipes.notes: Called 'sponsa solis' (sun's bride) or 'solsequium' (sun follower) because flower turns toward sun and closes at sunset. Also called 'wegwart/wegleg/wegwyß' (way-watcher). Cold and dry nature.

recipes.procedure_summary: Blue flowers distilled as soon as they open
recipes.notes: Blue flowers widely known. Eye remedy PROVEN often.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb distilled when fully ripe
key_uses: ALL SWELLING internal and external (THE NOBLEST water)
burns (THE BEST - immediate double cloth application)
scalded skin (draws out burn without harm)
all flux conditions (3x daily + external salve)
recipes.notes: ⭐ THE NOBLEST water for all swellings. THE BEST for burns. Author personally witnessed great help for intestinal cramping. Immediate application critical for burns.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb and root with all substance chopped and distilled mid-May
recipes.notes: Name 'centum nodia' = 100 knots (many joints in stem). Also called blood herb (sanguinaria) - holding it and staring at it stops bleeding through imagination. Clarifies: Latin 'gramen' = German 'weggraß', not hay.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb distilled
key_uses: St. Anthony's fire/wild fire/hellish fire (ignis persicus) - 3-4 fold cloth
recipes.notes: Entry at end of W section before X chapter marker.

recipes.procedure_summary: ROOT ONLY chopped small, distilled end of August
key_uses: purges melancholy/promotes bowel movement (1 quintlin with 3 lot wine, drink at 2 o'clock, fast until 9 o'clock)
paradoxical: HERB water STOPS bowel while ROOT water PROMOTES it
recipes.notes: Called 'Xpi wurtz' (Christ's root), 'nieß wurtz' (sneeze root) - causes sneezing when pounded. 130-year-old man Claus Holant of Strasbourg ate powder daily and remained healthy until natural death. PARADOXICAL: Root and herb have OPPOSITE effects.

recipes.procedure_summary: Root only crushed and distilled between the two Lady Days (Aug 15 - Sep 8)
key_uses: all chest diseases (EXTRAORDINARILY good - widens, softens, strengthens)
recipes.notes: Herb one span high with very sweet root like licorice (liquiricia), round like half a chestnut or small finger. Root is the sweet part.

recipes.procedure_summary: Shoots cut end of June, outer bark scraped off, middle bark (corticum medium) scraped and distilled end of May
recipes.notes: Name means 'the longer the sweeter' (ye lenger ye lieber) or 'bittersweet' (amare dulcis) - when chewed, starts bitter then becomes sweeter the longer you chew. Also called 'hinsch krut' (horse/deer herb) - hung around livestock necks. NOT the same as Aristolochia despite some confusion.

recipes.procedure_summary: Root chopped and distilled in first autumn month
key_uses: animal/worm bite causing speechlessness (3-5 times 1 lot - restores speech)
recipes.notes: Two types: common onion and sea onion (squilla/mörzybel/müßzybel) - grows near sea, water kills mice. Common onion widely known.

recipes.procedure_summary: Herb, root with all substance chopped and distilled mid-May
recipes.notes: Called 'maßlieblin' (little love-measure) - commonly known to many. First flower to appear in spring. Also 'consolida minor' for its healing properties.

recipes.procedure_summary: Root chopped and distilled end of May
key_uses: promotes bowel movement (8 lot at 3 o'clock, fast until 9)
St. Anthony's fire/holy fire/wild fire (3-4 fold cloth)
digestion improvement/throat phlegm (1-2x 3 lot, external throat rub)
recipes.notes: FINAL ENTRY IN ALPHABETICAL RECIPE BOOK. Also called 'hunds kürbs' (dog's gourd) or wild zitwan. Cross-references grape vine types (white bryony). Book 2 ends at line 21960.
